prep.title: Mise en Place & Weighing
prep.desc: Weigh all ingredients with a digital scale for 0.1g precision. {{waterAdvice}}
prep.grandma: Get all your ingredients ready on the counter. Use a scale! Cups are for coffee, not flour.
prep.science: Precision is key. A 5% variance in water can drastically change dough rheology (flow properties).
prep.critical: Do not let yeast come into direct contact with salt for prolonged periods before mixing.

brownie_melt.title: Melt Fat & Chocolate
brownie_melt.desc: Melt the butter (and chocolate, if using) gently over a double boiler or in short bursts in the microwave. Let cool slightly (to <45°C).
brownie_melt.grandma: Melt your butter and chocolate together. Don't burn it! Let it cool down a bit so it doesn't cook the eggs.
brownie_melt.science: Melting the fat rather than creaming it yields a denser, fudgier texture by reducing air incorporation.

brownie_ribbon.title: Ribbon Stage (Eggs & Sugar)
brownie_ribbon.desc: Whisk eggs and sugar vigorously until pale, thick, and falling in "ribbons" (approx 3-5 mins).
brownie_ribbon.grandma: Beat the eggs and sugar until they look white and fluffy, like a milkshake.
brownie_ribbon.science: Dissolving the sugar into the eggs creates a shiny, "papery" crust on top (meringue-like structure). Evaluating Ribbon stage ensures sufficient aeration.
brownie_ribbon.tip: If the sugar isn't fully dissolved, the crust will be dull.

brownie_fold.title: Emulsification & Folding
brownie_fold.desc: Stream the cooled chocolate/butter mixture into the egg foam while whisking gently. Then, FOLD in the sifted dry ingredients just until combined.
brownie_fold.grandma: Pour the chocolate into the eggs and mix. Then add the flour and fold it in gently with a spatula. Don't overmix!
brownie_fold.critical: Do not overmix after adding flour! Developing gluten creates a tough, rubbery brownie instead of a tender/fudgy one.

brownie_bake.title: Baking
brownie_bake.desc: Bake at {{temp}}°C ({{tempF}}°F). Test with a toothpick: it should come out with moist crumbs, not wet batter.
brownie_bake.grandma: Bake it until a toothpick comes out with a few sticky crumbs attached. If it's clean, you overbaked it!
brownie_bake.science: Brownies rely on egg protein coagulation and sugar crystallization for structure. Carry-over cooking is significant; pull them before they seem 100% done.

cookie_cream.title: Creaming (Butter & Sugar)
cookie_cream.desc: Beat softened butter and sugar(s) together until light, fluffy, and pale (3-5 mins).
cookie_cream.grandma: Mix the butter and sugar until it looks like light, fluffy frosting.
cookie_cream.science: The Creaming method punches millions of micro-air bubbles into the fat. These bubbles expand during baking (leavening), creating lift and texture.
cookie_cream.critical: Butter must be pliable (18-20°C) but not melted. Melted butter cannot hold air bubbles.

cookie_emulsify.title: Emulsification (Liquids)
cookie_emulsify.desc: Add eggs one at a time, beating well after each addition. Scrape down the bowl.
cookie_emulsify.grandma: Add the eggs one by one. Mix well so it doesn't look curdled.
cookie_emulsify.science: Eggs are mostly water; butter is fat. Incremental addition allows the lecithin in egg yolks to emulsify the water into the fat phase, preventing breaking.

cookie_dry.title: Incorporation (Dry Ingredients)
cookie_dry.desc: Add dry ingredients (flour, salt, leaveners) all at once. Mix on LOW speed just until streaks of flour disappear.
cookie_dry.grandma: Add the flour and mix slowly. Stop as soon as the white powder is gone.
cookie_dry.science: Minimize mixing time after adding flour to limit gluten development. Short gluten strands = tender cookies.

cookie_chill.title: Cold Maturation (Chilling)
cookie_chill.desc: Chill the dough for at least 2-24 hours before scooping/baking.
cookie_chill.grandma: Put the dough in the fridge for a few hours (or overnight). It makes better cookies!
cookie_chill.science: Chilling hydrates the flour (less spread), solidifies the fat (less spread), and allows enzymes to break down carbohydrates (browning/flavor).

cookie_bake.title: Baking
cookie_bake.desc: Bake at {{temp}}°C ({{tempF}}°F) until edges are set but centers are soft.
cookie_bake.grandma: Bake until the edges look golden brown. The center should still look a bit soft.
cookie_bake.science: Sugar caramelization and Maillard browning occur rapidly. The center will finish setting on the hot baking sheet out of the oven.

laminated_detrempe.title: Detrempe (Base Dough)
laminated_detrempe.desc: Mix flour, water, yeast, salt, sugar, and the dough-portion butter until just combined. Do not overdevelop gluten (keep extensible).
laminated_detrempe.grandma: Mix the dough ingredients just until they come together. Don't knead it too hard!
laminated_detrempe.science: Keeping the gluten structure slightly underdeveloped in the detrempe ensures extensibility for the subsequent lamination process.

laminated_block.title: Disk/Block Formation
laminated_block.desc: Flatten dough into a rectangle or disk, wrap tightly in plastic, and chill for 12-24 hours.
laminated_block.grandma: Flatten the dough, wrap it up, and put it in the fridge overnight.
laminated_block.science: Chilling relaxes the gluten and ensures the dough matches the temperature/consistency of the butter block for lamination.

laminated_lockin.title: Lock-in (Beurrage)
laminated_lockin.desc: Pound the butter block until pliable but cold (10-12°C). Encase it in the dough sheet.
laminated_lockin.grandma: Smash the butter until it bends but doesn't break. Wrap the dough around it.
laminated_lockin.critical: Butter and dough must have the same consistency to prevent shattering (too cold) or absorption (too warm).

laminated_tourage.title: Lamination (Tourage)
laminated_tourage.desc: Perform 1 Double Fold (Book) and 1 Simple Fold (Letter), resting 30m in fridge between folds.
laminated_tourage.grandma: Fold the dough like a book, then rest. Then fold like a letter. Keep it cold!
laminated_tourage.science: This process creates distinct alternating layers of fat and dough (55 layers for classic croissant) which puff upon baking.

laminated_shape.title: Shaping
laminated_shape.desc: Roll to 4mm thickness. Cut into triangles (10cm x 25cm). Elongate gently and roll tight. Egg wash.
laminated_shape.grandma: Roll it out thin, cut long triangles, and roll them up tight. Brush with egg.
laminated_shape.tip: Cut with a decisive, downward motion (pizza cutter) to avoid sealing the layers at the edges.

laminated_proof.title: Final Proof
laminated_proof.desc: Proof at 26-28°C (78-82°F) until doubled and jiggly (2-3h). Layers should separate slightly.
laminated_proof.grandma: Let them rise until they jiggle like jelly. Don't let it get too hot!
laminated_proof.critical: Avoid temperatures above 29°C (84°F) or the butter layers will melt, ruining the flaky structure.

laminated_bake.title: Baking
laminated_bake.desc: Bake at 200°C (390°F) for 5-7m, then lower to 190°C (375°F) for 12-15m until deep golden brown.
laminated_bake.grandma: Bake hot at first for puff, then lower the heat to finish cooking.
laminated_bake.science: Initial high heat creates steam for "oven spring" and separates layers before the crust sets.

poolish_prep.title: Prepare Poolish (Day -1)
poolish_prep.desc: Mix the Poolish flour and water (1:1 ratio) with the tiny amount of yeast. Cover and ferment for 12-16h at room temperature (18-20°C).
poolish_prep.grandma: Mix the poolish ingredients in a jar until it looks like pancake batter. Cover it and leave it on the counter overnight.
poolish_prep.science: Poolish is a 100% hydration preferment. It boosts protease activity (extensibility) and creates complex organic acids for flavor.
poolish_prep.tip: The poolish is ready when it is bubbly, doubled in size, and the center begins to collapse (the "drop").

biga_prep.title: Prepare Biga (Day -1)
biga_prep.desc: Mix Biga ingredients gently. Do not knead! You want a shaggy, unmixed mass. Ferment 16-24h at 16-18°C (60-64°F).
biga_prep.grandma: Mix the biga flour, water and yeast just enough so there is no dry flour. It should look lumpy and dry. Leave it overnight in a cool spot.
biga_prep.science: Biga is a stiff preferment (45-50% hydration). Its low water activity favors acetic acid production, giving strength and a complex, slightly sour flavor profile.
biga_prep.critical: Over-mixing the Biga will develop too much gluten too early, making it impossible to incorporate into the final dough.

levain_feed.title: Feed Levain
levain_feed.desc: Ensure your starter is active and fed 4-6 hours before mixing. It should be at peak rise.
levain_feed.grandma: Feed your sourdough starter so it is bubbly and happy before you start.
levain_feed.science: Using starter at peak activity ensures maximum yeast population and optimal pH balance (avoiding excessive acidity that degrades gluten).

autolyse.title: Autolyse
autolyse.desc: Mix only the Flour and Water until no dry flour remains. Cover and rest for 30-60 minutes. Do not add salt, yeast, or oil yet.
autolyse.grandma: Mix just the flour and water together. Let it sit for 30 mins. This helps the flour soak up the water.
autolyse.science: Autolyse allows protease enzymes to degrade some gluten bonds, increasing extensibility. It also fully hydrates starch and protein, reducing mixing time and oxidation.

mix_final.title: Final Mixing ({{method}})
mix_final.science: Salt is hygroscopic and strengthens gluten but dehydrates yeast. Oil coats gluten proteins and inhibits bond formation, so it must be added after the network is established.
mix_final.critical: Stop mixing if the dough exceeds 26°C (79°F) to prevent gluten degradation.

fold_coil.title: Coil Folds (Strength Building)
fold_coil.desc: Perform a set of Coil Folds every 30 minutes for the first 2 hours of bulk fermentation. Wet your hands to prevent sticking.
fold_coil.grandma: Every 30 mins, lift the dough up and let it fold under itself. Do this 3-4 times. It makes the dough strong.
fold_coil.science: High hydration doughs cannot be kneaded traditionally. Folding aligns gluten strands passively through gravity and extension, building structure without tearing.
fold_coil.tip: If the dough tears, let it rest 10 mins longer. Extensibility comes from rest; elasticity comes from folding.

knead_windowpane.title: Kneading & Windowpane
knead_windowpane.desc: Knead (by hand or machine) until the dough passes the Windowpane Test: it should stretch thin enough to see light through without tearing.
knead_windowpane.grandma: Knead the dough on the counter until it is smooth like a baby's bottom. It should bounce back when you poke it.
knead_windowpane.science: Mechanical action unfolds the protein coils (glutenin/gliadin) and encourages cross-linking (disulfide bonds), creating a viscoelastic network capable of trapping CO2.

bulk.title: Bulk Fermentation
bulk.desc: Allow the entire dough mass to ferment in a covered container until {{volume}}.
bulk.grandma: Let the dough sit in a bowl covered with plastic wrap until it looks puffy and has grown by about half.
bulk.science: Yeast converts sugars into CO2 (rise) and ethanol (flavor). Organic acids develop. The gluten network relaxes.
bulk.tip: Use a straight-sided container to accurately judge the volume increase.

cold_maturation.title: Cold Maturation (Retardation)
cold_maturation.desc: Place the dough in the fridge (4°C/39°F) for 24-72 hours.
cold_maturation.grandma: Put the dough in the fridge. You can leave it there for up to 3 days. The longer, the tastier.
cold_maturation.science: Cold temperatures slow yeast activity (CO2) but allow enzymatic activity (protease/amylase) and bacterial fermentation (LAB) to continue, developing complex flavors and digestibility.

staglio.title: Staglio (Divide & Ball)
staglio.desc: Divide dough into {{count}} equal portions. Shape into tight balls using surface tension.
staglio.grandma: Cut the dough into equal pieces. Roll them into tight, smooth balls.
staglio.science: Creating a "skin" of surface tension on the dough ball forces gases to expand upward rather than outward during the final proof.
staglio.critical: Close the bottom seam of the ball tightly to prevent gas leakage.

proof.title: Final Proof (Apprêt)
proof.desc: Cover dough balls and proof at room temperature until relaxed and soft to the touch (Poke Test).
proof.grandma: Cover the balls and let them rest on the counter until they look soft and pillowy. If you poke it, the dent should spring back slowly.
proof.science: The gluten relaxes (extensibility increases), allowing the dough to be stretched without snapping back. Yeast re-inflates the structure.
proof.tip: If the dough springs back immediately when poked, it needs more time. If the dent stays forever, it might be over-proofed.

bake.title: Baking & Oven Spring
bake.science: Rapid heat transfer causes Oven spring (gas expansion) before the crust sets. Maillard reaction occurs above 140°C (284°F), creating browning and flavor.
bake.critical: Do not overload with wet toppings, or the heat transfer will be blocked, resulting in a "gum line" (undercooked layer).

water.hot: Use cold water (4-10°C / 39-50°F) to counteract the warm room.
water.cold: Use warm water (25-28°C / 77-82°F) to wake up the yeast.

water_tip.hot: In hot environments, friction from mixing can overheat the dough. Cold water helps regulate this.
water_tip.cold: Yeast is sluggish in the cold. A warmer start helps kickstart fermentation.

action.default: Add yeast and mix. Then add salt. Finally, add oil (if using) once the dough has formed.
action.biga: Cut the Biga into small pieces into the water. Squeeze to break it up. Gradually add the remaining flour. Add salt last.
action.high_hydration: Add yeast and salt. Mix to develop structure. Then, slowly trickle in the remaining water (Bassinage) while mixing to maintain strength.

grandma.default: Add the yeast and mix it in. Then add the salt. If the recipe has oil, add it last.
grandma.biga: Break the stiff Biga into the water with your hands until it's milky. Then add the rest of the flour and salt.
grandma.high_hydration: Mix the yeast and salt in. Once it looks like dough, slowly add the rest of the water bit by bit.

action.default: Stretch gently. Top sparingly. Bake on pre-heated stone/steel.
action.pan: Press dough into oiled pan. Let rise again in pan for 30m. Top and bake.

grandma.default: Stretch it out, put your toppings on, and bake it hot!
grandma.pan: Push the dough into the pan. Let it rest a bit. Top and bake.

very_relaxed_easy_to_open_premium_textur: Very relaxed; easy to open. Premium texture and aroma.

weak_gluten_network_gas_escapes_easily_r: Weak gluten network. Gas escapes easily. Result: Dense, heavy crumb with irregular, often flat shape.
weakens_gluten_before_baking_soft_fragil: Weakens gluten before baking. Soft, fragile. Collapses under heat. Minimal rise.
